answers.author: Syed Murtuza
answers.text:
In City of Burlingame, there is no utility fee that covers the operation and management of storm water.  Essentially, the storm water management and operations is funded by General Funds.  However, the residents recently approved a storm drain fee to fund the City's storm drainage capital improvements program.

answers.author: Terri Birth
answers.text:
The City of Durham, NC funds 100% of our stormwater programs and maintenance with the Stormwater Utility Fee.  No other funding sources are used.  You can see our utility fee structure (which was approved and went into effect 7/1/2011) at http://www.durhamnc.gov/departments/works/stormwater_fee_increase.cfm.

answers.text:
Perhaps you've already seen this, but Black & Veatch periodically publishes a stormwater utility survey that provides some pretty good comparative information on utilities across the country.  It doesn't directly answer your question about stormwater quality funding.
http://www.bv.com/Markets/management_consulting/Stormwater_Survey.aspx
Florida has numerous stormwater utilities and the Florida Stormwater Association publishes annual survey reports that may provide you with some reference information as well - although it obviously only covers practices in one state.
http://www.florida-stormwater.org/content.asp?pl=8&sl=24&contentid=24
